The Secretary of State for Foreign affairs informed the Cabinet that the parliamentary opposition were likely to preds for a Debate onthe Optional Clause, in which questions of sealaw, belligerent rights, and so forth, were likely to be raised. One suggestion had beenthat he should circulate a Memorandum on thesubject as a White Paper.The Cabinet agreed (a) That the Secretary of State forForeign Affairs should prepare and circulate, for considerationby the Cabinet, a Memorandum onthe Optional Clause, in a formsuitable for publication as a white Paper, if so decided:(b) That, having regard to thedifficultios of finding Parlia-mentary time for a Debate, thequestion should be raised again at next Wednesday's Meeting "ofthe Cabinet. gjjggpjjOYMENT. 2. Paper No.337-0), and recommending,pending the results of the Disarmament Conference-,(i) That the work on the SingaporeBase should be slowed down asmuch as possible:(li) That all work that can be suspended should be suspended:(iii) That no new work should beembarked on.In approving the above recommendations of theFighting Servioes Committee, the Cabinet agreed -(a) That the Service Departments should confer immediately in regard to thearrangements for carrying out thedecision that all work that can be suspended should be suspended: i. e. ,x recommendation (ii) above:(b) That the First Lord of the admiralty should prepare, for considerationwith the Prime Minister, a Parlia-mentary announcement on the subjectof the Singapore Base:(c) That the Secretary of State forDominion Affairs should informthe Dominions of these decisions. THE UNEMPLOYMENTINSURANCE BILL.(previous reference:Cabinet 44(29), Con-conclusion 5.)6. In view of the Minister of Labour1 s reportthat the Unemployment Insurance Bill would haveto be introduced in Parliament early in thefollowing week, the Cabinet agreed To delegate to the Committee ofHome Affairs authority to approve the Bill, subject to the result ofa conference between the Ministerof Labour and the Chancellor ofthe Exchequer in regard to therates of benefit.-Q 1 i SLUMS.(previousBeferenoe:Cabinet 58(29), Con-elusion 2and Appendix.)7. The Cabinet had before them the following memoranda relating to Slum ConditionsA Memorandum by the Minister ofHealth (Paper CP.-296 (29))recalling that the Government had announced that one of the principalmeasures which they will introduce in the first Session of parliament will be a Bill to secure that slumconditions shall be effectivelydealt with, setting forth, for theconsideration of the Cabinet, the heads of a Slum Policy, and asking for the authority of his colleagues to proceed with the preparation ofa Bill on the lines indicated:A Memorandum by the Secretary ofState for Scotland (Paper CP.-297 (29)) dealing with the questionof slum clearance in Scotland, and urging, inter alia, that the unit of gpant"snbuld be" greater inScotland than in England, and thatin negotiations with the scottish local Authorities he should beauthorised to deal with them onthe understanding that he wouldmake the best possible bargainwith them but would not be limitedto the amount that may be determined for England.The Cabinet approved Inprinciple the proposals of theMinister of Health, as set forth in Paper No. CP. 296 (29),subject to consultation betweenthe Chancellor of the Exchequer,the Minister of Health, and theSecretary of Statie for Scotland,,on the subject of the unit basisof the grant to be. provided inEngland and Scotland respectively. TOWN PLANNING.(previous reference:Cabinet 56(29), Con-conclusion 2 and appendix.)8. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandumby the Minister of Health (Paper CP.-300 (29))pointing out that there has been much demand forthe extension of town planning to built-up areas by general legislation; and proposing that thepresent limits on the kinds of land to which town planning may be applied shall be removed, andthat the powers may be exercised for any lands,not only lands likely to be developed, but built,areas and also lands where at present there may beno likelihood of development. After setting forth the general nature of his proposals the Minister ofHealth stated that, before finally deciding thelines on which the amending legislation was to bedrawn, he proposed to consult the Local Authoritiesand other interests concerned, but that before doing so he would wish to be assured of thegeneral concurrence of the Cabinet in his views.The Oabinet approved in principle the proposals of the Ministerof Health, as set forth in paper No. CP. ^00 (29). He askedfor an early decision in case any alteration ofthe plans to be deposited in connection with theCharing Cross Bridge Scheme is approved.Recognising the importance of the futureprovision of aerodromes in London, and beingdisposed to favour in principle the ideas ofthe Secretary of State for Air on the subject,the Cabinet agreed (a) That the Secretary of State forAir should have authority toascertain whether his proposals in regard to Charing Cross Stationcould be carried out without involving any possibility of delay in the construction ofCharing Cross Bridge:(b) That, in the event of the CharingCross proposal not proving feasible,the Secretary of State should consider the possibility of alternative sites, e. g. , onLiverpool Street Station. 0 POOR 10.
